concepts.concept_name: Properties of materials: appearance, hardness, solubility, transparency
Grouping objects based on material properties
Materials that float or sink in water

in_scope: Grouping objects based on the material they are made of
Properties: appearance (colour, shape, size, texture)
Hardness: soft and hard materials
Solubility: soluble and insoluble substances in water
Transparency: transparent, translucent, opaque materials
Materials that float or sink in water
Lustre: shiny and dull materials
Metals and their properties (introduction)
Uses of materials based on their properties
out_of_scope: Chemical classification of elements and compounds — Class 7-8
Atomic structure and periodic table — Class 8-9
Density calculations for floating and sinking — Class 8

concepts.concept_name: Methods of separation: handpicking, winnowing, sieving, threshing
Separation using water: sedimentation, decantation, filtration

in_scope: Need for separating mixtures in daily life
Handpicking: removing unwanted substances by hand
Winnowing: separating husk from grain using wind
Sieving: separating mixtures of different-sized particles
Threshing: separating grain from stalks
Sedimentation: heavy particles settle down
Decantation: pouring off clear liquid
Filtration: separating insoluble solids from liquids using filter
Evaporation: obtaining dissolved solid from solution
Condensation: converting water vapour to liquid water
Saturated solution: no more solute dissolves
Unsaturated solution: more solute can dissolve
out_of_scope: Separation of elements and compounds — Class 8-9

concepts.concept_name: Expansion and contraction due to heating and cooling
Changes that can be reversed by changing conditions

in_scope: Reversible changes: can be reversed (e.g., melting of ice, stretching a rubber band)
Irreversible changes: cannot be reversed (e.g., burning of paper, cooking food)
Physical changes: no new substance formed, change in shape/size/state
Chemical changes: new substance formed (introduction)
Melting, freezing, evaporation as reversible changes
Burning, cooking, rusting as irreversible changes
Expansion of materials on heating
Contraction of materials on cooling
Dissolving and recovering substances

concepts.concept_name: Conservation of water and water scarcity
Properties of water as a solvent

in_scope: Sources of water: rivers, lakes, ponds, wells, rain
Three forms of water: solid (ice), liquid (water), gas (water vapour)
Water cycle: evaporation, condensation, cloud formation, precipitation
Importance of water for living things
Water as a universal solvent
Substances soluble and insoluble in water
Water scarcity and its causes
Conservation of water: rainwater harvesting, avoiding wastage
Drought and flood as water-related problems
Groundwater and its importance
out_of_scope: Water purification methods in detail — Class 7-8
Properties of water at molecular level — Class 9-10
